7b6b91f1-0a13-4f30-9b89-da91cee7ca54.description: The course objective is to provide an introduction to calculus with a focus on limits; derivatives; the differentiation of algebraic functions; the examination and uses of the maxima, minima, and convexity of functions; the definite integral; the fundamental theorem of integral calculus; and applications of integration. The traditional calculus course prepares students for upper level math courses. Note: University of Pittsburgh also grants this course for 3 credits; course number: MATH 0217.
7b6b91f1-0a13-4f30-9b89-da91cee7ca54.name: Fundamentals of Calculus I (MATH 0217)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include examinations, quizzes, and more with a minimum passing score of 70%.
Instructional strategies include: audio visual materials, discussion, computer-based training, practical exercises, lectures.

endorsements.description: This credential has been successfully evaluated by the American Council on Education for college credit. It is recommended for a total of 4 college credits. For more information about ACE Learning Evaluations, visit www.acenet.edu.

781013e4-638e-479f-b03f-f5037075daaa.description: The course objective is to introduce major topics in psychology that includes but are not limited to research & methods; culture; the brain; neurobiology; sensation and perception; learning; memory; thinking; intelligence; language; emotion and motivation; social psychology; developmental psychology; consciousness; personality; abnormal psychology; happiness; moral psychology, and criminal psychology. Note: University of Pittsburgh also grants this course for 3 credits; course number: PSY 0013.
781013e4-638e-479f-b03f-f5037075daaa.name: Introduction to Psychology (PSY 0013)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include examinations, quizzes, and more with a minimum passing score of 70%.

da07f116-06bf-46a1-8caa-3cc7bb304633.description: The course tours the history of the universe using modern technology and the constantly evolving knowledge of generations of astronomers and physicists. This course uses relevant and exciting discoveries to introduce light, the origin of the solar system, exoplanets, the lifecycles of stars, dead stars, the Milky Way and other galaxies, black holes, the Big Bang, dark matter and energy, and more. Note: University of Pittsburgh also grants this course for 3 credits; course number: ASTRON 0085.
da07f116-06bf-46a1-8caa-3cc7bb304633.name: Introduction to Astronomy (ASTRON 0085)

e4cb5dd3-e417-466c-bb5b-afaa0ff93df6.description: The course teaches foundational descriptive and inferential statistical procedures. Topics include but are not limited to descriptive statistics; probability; discrete and continuous random variables; the normal distribution; the central limit theorem; confidence intervals; correlation; f-distribution; and one-way ANOVA. Students will be introduced to statistical tools including Desmos and R. Note: University of Pittsburgh also grants this course for 3 credits; course number: STAT 0202).
e4cb5dd3-e417-466c-bb5b-afaa0ff93df6.name: Introduction to Statistics (STAT 0202)
